A partial-thromboplastin time mixing study is consistent with a factor deficiency. Assays of specific factors reveal a factor XII level of 15% (reference range, 60â€“140).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Proceed with surgery without additional treatment
Proceed with surgery, but administer cryoprecipitate before the procedure
Proceed with surgery, but administer vitamin K before the procedure
Proceed with surgery, but give fresh frozen plasma before the procedure
Proceed with surgery, but transfuse platelets before the procedure

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with deficiency of factor XII (Hageman factor deficiency) do not exhibit an increased bleeding diathesis despite the in vitro partial-thromboplastin time assay being prolonged. These patients can proceed directly to surgery without fresh frozen plasma or other interventions intended to correct the abnormal partial thromboplastin time.

Key learning point: The perioperative management for a patient with a prolonged partial-thromboplastin time and a low factor XII level is to proceed with surgery without additional treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryoprecipitate is primarily used as a source of fibrinogen, but it has been supplanted by safer recombinant or other plasma-derived preparations of factor VIII and von Willebrand factor. Cryoprecipitate is not a source of factor XII.

C) INCORRECT:

Factor XII is not a vitamin K-dependent coagulation factor and, therefore, vitamin K replacement would not be useful.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with deficiency of factor XII (Hageman factor deficiency) do not exhibit an increased bleeding diathesis despite the in vitro partial-thromboplastin time assay being prolonged. These patients can proceed directly to surgery without fresh frozen plasma or other interventions intended to correct the abnormal partial thromboplastin time.

E) INCORRECT:

A platelet transfusion is unnecessary in a nonbleeding patient with a normal platelet count.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman who is 3 weeks postpartum presents with a severe headache. She has no history of trauma and takes no medications. On further questioning, she notes that she had no problems with her recent delivery by caesarean section but has noticed increased gum bleeding with flossing during the past week. She denies any previous bleeding or family history of bleeding.
A complete blood count is within normal limits. Her prothrombin time is normal, but the activated partial-thromboplastin time is 90 seconds (reference range, 22.1â€“35.1). Noncontrast CT of the head demonstrates a small right subdural hematoma.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient's bleeding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lupus anticoagulant disorder is associated with prolonged activated partial-thromboplastin time, but it is not associated with increased bleeding risk.

B) INCORRECT:

Although type I von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, it is not as likely in this case as acquired factor VIII inhibitor. Patients with type I VWD often have a family history of bleeding and typically present at a younger age than this patient did. Although some patients with mild disease do not have a prior history of bleeding at their initial presentation, those with severe disease typically do. This patient's activated partial-thromboplastin time is 90 seconds, indicating severe disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Factor XIII deficiency causes a severe bleeding disorder, but it is not associated with a prolonged activated partial-thromboplastin time.

D) CORRECT:

The patient has an acquired bleeding disorder, and acquired factor VIII inhibitor is the most likely etiology. Autoantibodies to factor VIII may be seen in association with autoimmune syndromes or other diseases. One of the more frequent presentations is in the postpartum period, generally attributed to pregnancy-related changes in the immune system.

Acquired factor VIII inhibitor would be indicated by showing that mixing the patientâ€™s plasma with normal plasma did not correct the prolonged activated partial-thromboplastin time, and assays for factor VIII activity would show decreased activity.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a new-onset bleeding disorder in a previously healthy postpartum woman with a normal prothrombin time but a severely prolonged activated partial-thromboplastin time is acquired factor VIII inhibitor.

E) INCORRECT:

Factor XII deficiency is associated with prolonged activated partial-thromboplastin time, but it is not associated with increased bleeding risk.

She recalls an episode of extensive bleeding when her wisdom teeth were removed. She has never had any other surgical procedures and says she does not use aspirin or other nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.
Her platelet function is normal, and her international normalized ratio is 0.9.
Other laboratory results are as follows:

What diagnosis is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hemophilia B is associated with similar symptoms (including soft-tissue bleeding, postprocedural bleeding, and hemarthrosis), but it is caused by a factor IX deficiency, which this patient does not have.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome would typically cause a hypercoagulable state rather than bleeding.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with von Willebrand disease present with moderate-to-severe symptoms of mucocutaneous, soft-tissue, joint, or urinary bleeding â€” or excessive bleeding after medical or dental procedures. Type 2N von Willebrand disease is caused by mutations in von Willebrand factor that affect the binding site for factor VIII, leading to impaired binding and therefore rapid clearance of factor VIII, as well as low levels of factor VIII similar to those characteristic of hemophilia A. However, the level of von Willebrand factor antigen is often normal, because the mutation affects the function rather than the level of von Willebrand factor.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young adult with recurrent bleeding whose partial-thromboplastin time mixing study corrects with normal plasma and who has normal factor IX levels is von Willebrand disease.

D) INCORRECT:

An acquired factor VIII inhibitor would cause a prolonged partial-thromboplastin time that does not correct with mixing. In addition, this patient's lifelong tendency to bleed with minor surgical procedures and to bruise with minor trauma suggests an inherited rather than an acquired bleeding disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

A platelet-storage disorder or Glanzmann thrombasthenia would yield an abnormal platelet function screen, should not cause a decrease in factor VIII, and would primarily manifest as mucosal bleeding and petechiae.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman is hospitalized for an elective left knee replacement. One day after surgery, her hospital course is complicated by a large ecchymosis at the incision site, severe swelling of the left knee with excruciating pain, and continued postoperative bleeding from the wound.
Her hemoglobin level is 10.0 g/dL (reference range, 12.0â€“16.0), compared with a preoperative value of 14.2 g/dL.
Other postoperative laboratory results are as follows:

Mixing the patientâ€™s plasma 1:1 with plasma that contains 100% of the normal factor level does not change the activated partial-thromboplastin time. A platelet-function screen is normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The fact that the presence of adequate levels of clotting factors does not correct the activated partial-thromboplastin time in the mixing study suggests that the patientâ€™s plasma contains a factor that inhibits one of the clotting factors, most commonly factor VIII. Most acquired inhibitors are antibodies. Treatment of acquired inhibitors of coagulation factors should have two goals: controlling the bleeding and eliminating the inhibitor. Given that this patient is bleeding excessively after surgery, administration of either activated prothrombin complex concentrates or recombinant human factor VIIa is required in order to bypass the factor VIII inhibitor.

Key learning point: A prolonged activated partial-thromboplastin time that is not corrected by a mixing study suggests the presence of a factor inhibitor, most commonly a factor VIII inhibitor.

B) INCORRECT:

Administering fresh frozen plasma helps to improve coagulopathies related to factor deficiencies but not those related to factor inhibitors.

C) INCORRECT:

In the long term, the patient will require prednisone (and/or additional immunosuppressive therapy) to control the autoimmune inhibitor, but that would take too long to control the acute bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Given that the patientâ€™s platelet count and function are normal, a platelet transfusion would not help control the bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

The prothrombin time is normal, so a vitamin K deficiency that requires correction is unlikely.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old previously healthy man reports gingival bleeding after brushing his teeth. He also reports pinpoint purple "dots" on the periocular area after an episode of vomiting. He started taking trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a cellulitis one week before these episodes. He has had no recent fevers or upper respiratory tract infections.
Which one of the following tests would be most likely to reveal the cause of this patientâ€™s skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Testing for activated partial thromboplastin time is typically used to detect coagulation disorders such as clotting-factor deficiencies, defects, or inhibitors. Patients with coagulation disorders typically present with large ecchymoses and deep hematomas. Often, the bleeding associated with coagulation disorders is delayed, whereas patients with thrombocytopenia tend to bleed immediately.

B) CORRECT:

A low platelet count and defects in platelet function may manifest clinically as petechiae or mucosal bleeding. Petechiae are recognizable by their pinpoint size and nonblanching purple color. Valsalva maneuvers, such as coughing, defecating, or vomiting, can induce petechiae on the face in a patient with thrombocytopenia. There are many causes of thrombocytopenia, but drug-induced thrombocytopenia and immune thrombocytopenia are among the most common. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is among the medications that can induce acute thrombocytopenia.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of petechiae and gingival bleeding is thrombocytopenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Testing for prothrombin time is typically used to detect coagulation disorders such as clotting-factor deficiencies, defects, or inhibitors. Patients with coagulation disorders typically present with large ecchymoses and deep hematomas. Often, the bleeding associated with coagulation disorders is delayed, whereas patients with thrombocytopenia tend to bleed immediately.

D) INCORRECT:

The direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is used to detect autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which does not manifest with petechiae or mucosal bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Von Willebrand factor plays a crucial role in hemostasis by binding platelets to endothelial surfaces. It also contributes to fibrin clot formation, serving as a carrier protein for factor VIII. Because of its role in binding platelets, a deficiency in von Willebrand factor can manifest as petechiae. However, it is typically not acute in onset and would not be induced by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a nosebleed that started when she woke up this morning and has continued on and off for more than 2 hours. She has no history of trauma. Her parents report that she gets nosebleeds every 1 to 2 months but that the bleeding usually stops with constant pressure. The nosebleeds are not seasonal. Her family history is significant for heavy, prolonged menses in some relatives on her motherâ€™s side.
The girl is playful and appears well but has dried blood around the right nostril. Her mucous membranes are moist, and her conjunctivae are pink. Her heart, lung, and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. She has multiple bruises in various stages of healing on both lower extremities below the shins. No petechiae are evident.
A peripheral smear reveals no abnormal cells or platelet clumping. Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
7000
5000â€“14,500


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.0
11.5â€“15.5


Hematocrit (%)
39.0

355,000
150,000â€“450,000

12.0
11.0â€“14.0


Partial thromboplastin time (sec)
27.0
22.0â€“35.0


What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Bleeding time, platelet-function testing, and platelet-aggregation testing
Factor VIII and factor IX activity
Von Willebrand factor (VWF) antigen, VWF activity, and factor VIII activity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If thrombocytopenia and von Willebrand disease are both ruled out, platelet function may be assessed using platelet-aggregation testing. Bleeding time is not routinely performed as a screening test in children.

B) INCORRECT:

Factor VIII deficiency (hemophilia A) and factor IX deficiency (hemophilia B) are the most common inherited coagulation disorders. Initial testing for coagulation defects includes PT and PTT, which are normal in this case. Further testing for specific factor deficiencies would be pursued if the PT and PTT were abnormal.

C) INCORRECT:

Skeletal survey and retinal examination would be indicated if there were concern for nonaccidental trauma. In this case, bruising is found only on the patientâ€™s shins, a high-impact area not typically considered to raise suspicion for abuse.

D) INCORRECT:

Prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT) are appropriate tests in evaluating disorders of secondary hemostasis, such as hemophilia. Thrombin time and fibrinogen level are specific measurements of fibrinogen quantity and activity; abnormal values are rare and are most likely to be caused by liver disease, malignancy, or medication use. In the absence of relevant risk factors, thrombin time and fibrinogen level are not appropriate initial tests for this child.

E) CORRECT:

A nontraumatic nosebleed lasting more than 2 hours is abnormal and requires further workup.

The first step in evaluating bleeding is to determine whether the disorder is one of primary hemostasis, which refers to platelet aggregation and plug formation, or of secondary hemostasis, which is generated by the coagulation cascade. This patientâ€™s epistaxis, bruising, and family history of heavy menstrual bleeding suggest a disorder of primary hemostasis. A coagulation-factor deficiency would manifest with bleeding into soft tissues, muscles, and joints.

When a disorder of primary hemostasis is suspected, a complete blood count should be performed to evaluate for thrombocytopenia, and a peripheral smear should be obtained to rule out clumping and to evaluate platelet morphology. When these tests are normal, as in this case, further testing is indicated.

Von Willebrand disease, due to either qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor (VWF), is the most frequently inherited bleeding disorder and, after thrombocytopenia, is the most common disorder of primary hemostasis. Testing for von Willebrand disease includes measuring both VWF antigen (blood levels of VWF) and VWF activity (ability of VWF to bind properly to platelets). It also includes factor VIII activity because factor VIII circulates attached to VWF, and a diminished amount of factor VIII may indicate a diminished amount of VWF.

Key learning point: Epistaxis, mucosal bleeding, and heavy menstrual bleeding are signs and symptoms consistent with disorders of primary hemostasis.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy with congenital heart disease presents for evaluation of daily prolonged nosebleeds. His mother reports that they last up to one hour, are not localized to one nostril, and eventually stop with pressure. The patient has not had any facial or other trauma, but his mother has noticed more frequent bruising recently and small red dots on his lower extremities.
The patientâ€™s current medications are daily aspirin, nightly amlodipine, and occasional diphenhydramine for allergic rhinitis. He had an uncomplicated tonsillectomy at 2 years of age and is otherwise healthy with no significant bleeding history.
On examination, he appears well and is in no acute distress. He has a temperature of 37.5Â°C, a heart rate of 86 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Dried blood is evident around his right nostril, and he has scattered bruises on his upper and lower extremities. He also has a few petechiae on his chest and feet. His lungs are clear, his cardiac examination is normal, and he has no hepatosplenomegaly.
The results of a complete blood count are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
6300
5500â€“15,500


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.0
11.5â€“13.5

37

388,000
150,000â€“450,000


Prothrombin time (sec)
12

Partial thromboplastin time (sec)
33
22â€“35


What is the most likely etiology of this patientâ€™s nosebleeds?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Type 3 von Willebrand disease involves a near absence of von Willebrand factor, leading to severe bleeding early in life. Although von Willebrand disease could manifest similarly to this patientâ€™s condition, his normal tonsillectomy and lack of other bleeding history rule out type 3 von Willebrand disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K deficiency can manifest with easy bruising and mucosal bleeding but would result in a prolonged prothrombin time.

C) INCORRECT:

Factors VIII and IX deficiency (hemophilia A and B) are inherited bleeding disorders that manifest early in life with spontaneous bleeding that is more likely to be deep tissue than mucocutaneous. This patient has no history of major bleeding and underwent a tonsillectomy without complication, making hemophilia unlikely. His normal coagulation studies (prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time) further rule out hemophilia.

D) CORRECT:

Mucocutaneous bleeding â€” including epistaxis, bleeding from the mouth or gums, petechiae, and easy bruising â€” is associated with qualitative and quantitative platelet disorders. In contrast, deep-tissue bleeding, including into muscle and soft tissue, is characteristic of a factor deficiency such as hemophilia.

This patient has mucocutaneous bleeding and a normal platelet count, suggesting a qualitative platelet disorder. The most common cause of platelet dysfunction is a medication effect, and in this case, aspirin is the most likely culprit. Aspirin inhibits cyclooxygenase, blocking thromboxane A2 production and thus impairing platelet aggregation.

Key learning point: Use of aspirin may cause bleeding secondary to impaired platelet aggregation and adhesion.

E) INCORRECT:

Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a rare autosomal recessive bleeding disorder, causes a deficiency in glycoprotein Ib, the receptor for von Willebrand factor, and is associated with both qualitative and quantitative platelet defects. This patientâ€™s normal platelet count and lack of previous bleeding complications make Bernard-Soulier syndrome an unlikely cause of his epistaxis.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl comes to the pediatrician for a follow-up appointment 10 days after an urgent care visit for heavy menstrual bleeding. She reports that her first menstrual period started 15 days ago. There was no significant pain, but she had to change her pad every 3 hours, and she bled through to her clothes and bedsheets several times. Her mother brought her to the urgent care center on the 5th day of her period, where they drew labs and prescribed her oral iron supplements to take daily, and birth control pills to take every 6 hours until the bleeding stopped. The bleeding stopped the following day, after which she completed a three-day tapering regimen of the birth control pills.
The patient reports that she is quite tired and has a headache. She has no significant medical history. The patient is adopted and family history is unknown. She has never been sexually active.
Vital signs are within normal limits. A complete physical examination is notable only for pallor and mild comedonal acne.
Laboratory results from the urgent care visit are as follows:
